[[Distinguished Service Order]] | relations = | laterwork = Company director }} [[Admiral (Royal Navy)|Admiral]] Sir '''William Gerrard "Bill" Andrewes''' [[Order of the British Empire|KBE]] [[Order of the Bath|CB]] [[Distinguished Service Order|DSO]] (3 November 1899 – 21 November 1974) was a [[Royal Navy]] officer who served in [[World War I]] and [[World War II]], commanded the British and Commonwealth Naval Forces and United Nations Task Force 95 during the [[Korean War]], and went on to command of the [[North America and West Indies Station|America and West Indies Squadron]] and served as [[Supreme Allied Commander Atlantic|Deputy Supreme Allied Commander, Atlantic]].{{Cite web |url= http://www.unithistories.com/officers/RN_officersA5.html |title=Royal Navy Officers 1939-1945 (An-Ap) |work=unithistories.com |accessdate=3 December 2010 }} ==Biography== ===Education and early career=== William Andrewes was the second son of [[The Reverend|the Rev.]] Canon Gerrard Thomas Andrewes, [[Canon (priest)|Canon]] of [[Winchester Cathedral|Winchester]], and Helena Louisa Kirby. He was educated at [[Twyford School]], Winchester, before entering the Royal Naval College at [[Royal Naval College, Osborne|Osborne]] in September 1912, moving to [[Britannia Royal Naval College|Dartmouth]] in 1914. Andrewes was assigned to the battleship {{HMS|Canada|1913|2}} in August 1915, seeing action at the [[Battle of Jutland]] in May 1916. From February 1917 he attended the torpedo control officer's course, and was assigned to the destroyer {{HMS|Walrus|1917|2}} for service in the [[Baltic Sea]] in February 1918. He received his commission as a [[Sub-Lieutenant|sub-lieutenant]] on 15 May 1918, and promotion to [[lieutenant]] on 15 October 1919. Andrewes attended various short training courses in 1920 before serving aboard the destroyer ''Versatile'' into 1921. Between September 1921 and June 1923 he attended the torpedo officer's "long course" in torpedoes, mines, and electrical engineering at the [[Old Royal Naval College|Royal Naval College]] at [[Greenwich]] and at the torpedo school at [[HMS Vernon (shore establishment)|HMS ''Vernon'']] at [[Portsmouth]]. He was then an instructor at HMS ''Vernon'' until December 1924. Andrewes served as Torpedo Officer aboard the submarine depot ship ''Ambrose'' of the 4th Submarine Flotilla on the [[China Station]] until February 1927. He returned to ''Vernon'' as an instructor until August 1929, receiving promotion to [[Lieutenant Commander|lieutenant-commander]] on 15 October 1927. From 6 January 1930 Andrewes served as Torpedo Officer on the battleship {{HMS|Warspite|03|2}} in the [[Mediterranean Fleet|Mediterranean]] and [[Atlantic Fleet (United Kingdom)|Atlantic Fleet]]s, then from 30 April 1931 aboard the heavy cruiser {{HMS|Kent|54|2}} as Torpedo Officer, as well as Fleet Torpedo Officer for the 5th Cruiser Squadron, on the China Station. On 31 December 1932 he was promoted to [[commander]]. Andrewes spent almost all of the year 1934 attending a course at the Royal Navy Staff College at Greenwich, before serving as the Fleet Torpedo Officer in the 2nd Battle Squadron, [[Home Fleet]], aboard the battleship {{HMS|Nelson|28|2}} from January 1935 to January 1937. He then spent six weeks in charge, as Executive Officer, of {{HMS|Warspite|03|2}} as that battleship was being extensively refitted at Portsmouth. After a tactical course at Portsmouth, he served as Executive Officer of the battleship {{HMS|Rodney|29|2}} in the Home Fleet from 26 July 1937 until receiving promotion to the rank of [[Captain (Royal Navy)|captain]] on 30 June 1938. ===World War II=== In 1939 he served on the Joint Planning Staff of the [[Committee of Imperial Defence]], then as Commanding Officer of the seaplane carrier {{HMAS|Albatross|1928|2}} into 1940, before a short period as Chief Staff Officer at [[Dover]]. On 8 April 1940 he was appointed Assistant Director of the Plans Division at the [[Admiralty]], not returning to sea duty until 19 September 1942 when he took command of the cruiser {{HMS|Uganda|66|2}} for service in the Atlantic and Mediterranean, taking part in "Operation Husky", the [[Allied invasion of Sicily]], in JulyâAugust 1943, (for which he received a [[Mentioned in Despatches|Mention in Despatches]]) and in "Operation Avalanche", the [[Allied invasion of Italy#Salerno landings|landings at Salerno]], in September 1943 (for which he was awarded the [[Distinguished Service Order]]). On 28 February 1944 he was appointed Deputy Chief of Staff to the [[Commander-in-Chief, Portsmouth]] for administration and duties in preparation for the [[Normandy landings]], with the rank of [[Commodore (Royal Navy)|commodore]], 2nd class. From November 1944 until July 1945 he served as Chief Staff Officer to Vice-Admiral James William Rivett-Carnac, who as Vice-Admiral (Q) was responsible for the entire logistical operation to support the [[British Pacific Fleet]].{{Cite web |url= http://www.navy.gov.au/w/images/Hobbs_THE_BRITISH_PACIFIC_FLEET_IN_1945.pdf |title=The British Pacific Fleet in 1945 |author= Hobbs, David |work=navy.gov.au |accessdate=2 December 2010 }} ===Post-war and Korea=== Andrewes was appointed Commanding Officer of the aircraft carrier {{HMS|Formidable|67|2}} in August 1945, but a knee injury prevented him from assuming the post, and instead he commanded the carrier {{HMS|Indomitable|92|2}} from December 1945 into 1947. He then served as Chief of Staff to Commander-in-Chief Portsmouth, and was appointed Naval [[Aide-de-camp]] to [[George VI of the United Kingdom|the King]] in July. In December 1947 he was appointed Senior Naval Member of the Directing Staff of the [[Imperial Defence College]], and was promoted to [[Rear Admiral (Royal Navy)|rear admiral]] on 8 January 1948. He was promoted to [[Vice Admiral (Royal Navy)|vice admiral]] on 1 December 1950, and on the 17th was made commander of the 5th Cruiser Squadron and Second-in-Command, [[Eastern Fleet|Far Eastern Fleet]], flying his flag in the [[light cruiser]] {{HMS|Belfast|C35|2}}. After the outbreak of the [[Korean War]] in June 1950 he commanded British and Commonwealth Naval Forces, with the carrier {{HMS|Theseus|R64|2}} as his flagship. He had two aircraft carriers available at any one time which he worked in eighteen day cycles.{{Cite web |url= http://www.britains-smallwars.com/carriers/Theseus.html |title=HMS ''Theseus'' |work=britains-smallwars.com |accessdate=3 December 2010 }} and then United Nations Task Force 95 (comprising all Blockade and Escort ships in Korean waters) in 1951. From 15 October 1951 he served as Commander-in-Chief of the [[North America and West Indies Station|America and West Indies Station]], and also as [[Supreme Allied Commander Atlantic|Deputy Supreme Allied Commander, Atlantic]], (DSACLANT) from 1952, until 1953. Promoted to [[Admiral (Royal Navy)|admiral]] on 24 November 1954 he served as President of the Royal Naval College at Greenwich until 1956. Admiral Andrewes retired on 10 January 1957, and became a director of the shipbuilders [[John I. Thornycroft & Company]] having become a member of the [[Institution of Electrical Engineers]] in May 1956. He died on 21 November 1974. ==Personal life== He married Frances Audrey Welchman in 1927. They had one son and one daughter. ==Awards== Admiral Andrewes was the recipient of numerous awards and distinctions, as well as [[campaign medal]]s for World War I, World War II, and the Korean War. * [[File:Order of St John (UK) ribbon.png|33px]] Commander of the [[Venerable Order of Saint John]], 1964 * [[File:Order of St John (UK) ribbon.png|33px]] Officer of the Venerable Order of Saint John, 1960 * [[File:SVE SvÃ¤rdsorden BAR.svg|33px]] Knight of the ''Kungliga SvÃ¤rdsorden'' (Swedish Royal [[Order of the Sword]]), 1954 * [[File:Us legion of merit chief commander rib.png|33px]] Commander of the [[Legion of Merit]] (United States), 1953 * [[File:Order BritEmp rib.png|33px]] Knight Commander of the [[Order of the British Empire]] (KBE), 1951 * [[File:Silver Star ribbon.svg|33px]]
